TaggedPDF-doc.P: The submission script lives in our course directory (/afs/umich.edu/class/eecs280), and is called "submit280". The syntax for running the script is:

/afs/umich.edu/class/eecs280/submit280 <projnum> <files...> where <projnum> is the project number, and <files> is the list of files that you are submitting. To use it, you must be in the CAEN environment.
First, type in the following commands: % cd % cd <path-to-your-project-directory> % ls p1.cpp
(this will also list out the remaining files in your directory)
then type this in to submit your file for project 1: % /afs/umich.edu/class/eecs280/submit280 1 p1.cpp It'll ask you something like this:
p1.cpp Testing with published test case Submit these files? Type y or RETURN to submit, anything else to abort: Press enter to submit your file.
The submit280 script performs some simple checks.

LI.LBody: Do you have the right number of files, with the right names?
Are you submitting from the CAEN environment?
Does your submission compile as specified in the handout?

Does it pass the published test case? CAEN environment: You have to use CAEN to submit your project files. You must ssh to: login.engin.umich.edu and perform all final testing and submissions from there. If you have the wrong names/number of files, you won't be able to

TaggedPDF-doc.P: submit at all. If you are submitting from somewhere other than the CAEN environment, you *might* be able to submit, but might not. If
your program does not compile or pass the published test cases, you can submit, but you are unlikely to earn much in the way of a score for the project.
PLEASE PAY ATTENTION TO THESE WARNINGS!

Submissions are copied into a dropbox directory in AFS. It is set up so that you can insert new files, but no one can read anyone else's files, and no one can modify or delete even their own. This is the only place submissions are stored, so be *sure* to keep a copy in your own AFS directory, just in case.
